description.narrative: Bosnia and Herzegovina Biomass Energy for Employment and Energy Security Project

title.narrative: GEF Biomass 3880 Terminal Evaluation report final 3

description.narrative: Increase market demand for biomass energy, strengthen and expand biomass fuel market and supply chain, convince policy makers, financial sector, fuel and technology suppliers and niche markets of benefits and market opportunities for biomass energy.

Revised indicators for period 2016-2019 1. At least one policy review document adopted until the end of the project duration. 2. Updated Biomass related REAP of BiH and adopted for use in practice until January 2018. 3. Identification, quantification and mapping of biomass exploitation in BiH developed until December 2018 4. Forest governance mechanisms developed to support best practices (forestry practices, BAT and operational methods) and recommendations to increase utilization and quality of wood biomass . 5. At least three RES infrastructure projects implemented until the end of 2018, at least another 6 RES infrastructure projects implemented based on newly developed financial schemes until 2020.
Indicators for period 2009-2015 1. no. of schools with biomass boilers totalling 5200 tCO2e in direct emissions reductions 2. no. of regions where business model has been replicated 3. amount of sustainably sourced biomass fuelwood supplied at competitive price 4. reduction of perceptions of fuel supply risk based on consumer confidence survey 5. percentage increase in biomass energy awareness and capacity in project area

comment.narrative:
Revised baseline for 2016-2019 period: 1. No policy review documents related to wood biomass 2. REAP of BiH does not include specific wood biomass segments and targets 3. No exact data on biomass exploitation in BiH 4. No forest governance mechanisms in place to directly support utilization and quality of wood biomass . 5. Zero infrastructure projects
Baseline for 2009-2015 period 1. (0) zero schools with biomass boilers 2. (0) zero regions where business model has been replicated 3. (0) amount of sustainably sourced certified biomass fuelwood supply 4. (0) perceptions of fuel supply risk not recorded-no consumer confidence survey 5. (0) no impact surveys on awareness, perceptions and capacity of biomass energy
Inception phase of the follow-up project 1.Establishment of the project board 2. First Project board meeting held 3. Establishment of donor coordination for RES

1.Establishment of the project board (MoFTER, Min of forestry of FBiH and Min of Forestry of RS, CzDA) 2. First Project board meeting held 3. Establishment of donor coordination for RES among international agencies (UNDP, USAID EIA, GiZ) - initial programme coordination on bio-energy established and joint programme presented to the stakeholders

description.narrative: Enhancing BIH Environmental Policies planning by introducing and developing local environmental and energy action plans
The Green Economic Development project aims is to contribute to the creation of a favorable environment for investing in EE measures in BiH.

1. Number of trained energy professionals. 2. Number of cantons that introduced institutionalization of energy, costs and emission management and monitoring in public sector buildings of BiH imposed. 3. Number of sustainable financial mechanisms within Environmental Protection Funds developed and adopted. 4. Number of public buildings where energy efficiency measures were implemented. 5. Number of energy efficiency campaigns executed.

comment.narrative: # Description TARGET 2016 1.1. Number of detailed energy audits assessed, prioritized and ranked by Environment Funds - 40 1.2. Number of energy professionals participating on training programme for skills and knowledge development - 100 1.3. 30 female energy professionals participated on training programme for skills and knowledge development - 30 1.4. Number of detailed energy audits conducted - 40 1.5. Number of investment decisions made based on evaluation of detailed energy audits - 20 1.6. Number of Fund staff (FBiH and RS each) participating on annual capacity development training on energy efficiency, EMIS and EE policy - 10 1.7. Fund staff (FBiH and RS each) actively working on EMIS/EE investment decision making process cycle, monitoring, assessing and evaluating energy indicators - 4 1.8. Number of sub-national authorities with reporting mechanisms in place target value: 7 (eg 5 cantons in FBiH, 2 ministries in RS) - 4 1.9. Number of public sector buildings monitored through EMIS database - 3000 2.0. Number of end-users trained on EMIS * Number of buildings with trained user - 3000 2.1. description.narrative: Democratic Green Economic Development - Securing access to water and sustainable water management

title.narrative: 00050813_MDGF BiH EG JPD Signed Cover Page ENG
ProDoc_GoAL Wash WATSAN Regulatory Framework in BH

description.narrative: Improved economic governance in water utility companies for better services to citizens in targeted municipalities.
1. Number of desk review/map of stakeholders prepared. 2. Number of studies for establishment of a regulatory framework. 3. Number of methodologies for setting water supply and wastewater tariffs.

comment.narrative: 1. 2 Water utility companies identified to test the Tariff setting methodology for water supply and wastewater 2. 4 workshops held for water utility companies on the subject of Tariff setting methodology for water supply and wastewater

1. Two water utility companies have been testing the Tariff setting methodology for water supply and wastewater since October 2016. Those are Tesanj in Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina and Teslic in Republika Srpska, 2. 4 workshops held for water utility companies on the subject of Tariff setting methodology for water supply and wastewater in following locations: Sarajevo, Mostar, Doboj and Banja Luka. Total number of participants 140.

activity-description.narrative: Support to population, private business and local government in Srebrenica in Bosnia and Herzegovina

description.narrative: 1. % of investments in support to competitiveness. 2. % increase of officially registered employees in the region compared to the average for Bosnia and Herzegovina. 3. % increase of revenues in retail trade. 4. Difference between the average gross income of rural families and the average gross salary. 5. Number of effective and functional public-private dialogue mechanisms.

comment.narrative: 1. Limited competitiveness of the Srebrenica region (to be calculated at the beginning of the project). 2. 5,139 officially registered employees in the region (2012). 3. Turnover of retail trade amounts to BAM 48,606,000 in 2012. 4. Average gross income of rural families is 50% lower than the average gross salary (around BAM 1,200). 5. No structured dialogue between the public and private sectors.

1. 10% compared to 2013 2. 10% compared to 2013 3. At least 5% higher than the inflation 4. At least 1% higher 5. 20% lower than the average gross salary 6. Implemented at least three initiatives proposed by the PPD working groups

SWISS AGENCY FOR DEVELOPMENT AND COOPERATION - SDC
SWISS AGENCY FOR DEVELOPMENT AND COOPERATION - SDC
SWISS AGENCY FOR DEVELOPMENT AND COOPERATION - SDC
SWISS AGENCY FOR DEVELOPMENT AND COOPERATION - SDC

description.narrative: Project started in 2015. 1. Quality of water management in relevant partner municipalities determined through assessment in order to identify weak points and appropriate measures for improvement. 2. Coordination between partners at local, state, entity, cantonal and local government levels enhanced through joint design of concrete initiatives for the Main Phase. 3. Quality of business friendly environment and economic conditions in relevant partner municipalities determined through assessment.

comment.narrative:
Project started in 2015.
1. Poor quality of water management and infrastructure in local governments leads to distribution losses of up to 50 %, increasing cost of water. 2. Insufficient coordination between local governments, water utilities, sectoral ministries at entity and cantonal levels for the sake of better service delivery management capacity and accountability. 3. Despite positive experiences, including pilot business-friendly certification, local governments in Bosnia and Herzegovina still lack sound economic expertise and tools to engage in productive public-private dialogue and increase investment attractiveness of their localities through viable business infrastructure, support to employability and local entrepreneurship.

1. Prepare draft Public Service Agreements (PSAs) detailing roles and responsibilities in terms of water supply and wastewater management services in target localities, including concrete oversight by LG councils and citizens utility performance. Share with all 18 LGs and seek approval of PSA wording. 2. Initiate activities on addressing key regulatory gaps related to local service delivery in the environmental and economic sectors. 3. Develop methodology and questionnaires for conducting an initial Citizen Satisfaction Survey in all 18 partner local governments. Distribute results for each partner Local government and publish results, which will be used for baseline on citizen satisfaction levels with local authorities.

Main phase officially started in June 2016. 1. Prepared draft Public Service Agreements (PSAs) detailing roles and responsibilities in terms of water supply and wastewater management services in target localities, including concrete oversight by LG councils and citizens utility performance. Drafts shared with all 18 LGs for agreement on PSA wording and initiated preparations for adoption on LG level. 2. Initial assessment conducted and basic legal gaps identified and recommendations provided for both environmental and economic sectors, with input from all project stakeholders from public and private sectors. 3. Developed methodology and questionnaires for conducting an initial Citizen Satisfaction Survey in all 18 partner local governments. Completed surveys for 5,750 individual survey responses. Distributed and published results for each partner Local government. Established baseline on citizen satisfaction levels with local authorities as of 2016 year-end.

description.narrative: Project started in 2015. 1. Quality of water management in relevant partner municipalities determined through assessment in order to identify weak points and appropriate measures for improvement. 2. Coordination between partners at local, state, entity, cantonal and local government levels enhanced through joint design of concrete initiatives for the Main Phase. 3. Quality of business friendly environment and economic conditions in relevant partner municipalities determined through assessment.

comment.narrative:
Project started in 2015.
1. Poor quality of water management and infrastructure in local governments leads to distribution losses of up to 50 %, increasing cost of water. 2. Insufficient coordination between local governments, water utilities, sectoral ministries at entity and cantonal levels for the sake of better service delivery management capacity and accountability. 3. Despite positive experiences, including pilot business-friendly certification, local governments in Bosnia and Herzegovina still lack sound economic expertise and tools to engage in productive public-private dialogue and increase investment attractiveness of their localities through viable business infrastructure, support to employability and local entrepreneurship.

1. Prepare draft Public Service Agreements (PSAs) detailing roles and responsibilities in terms of water supply and wastewater management services in target localities, including concrete oversight by LG councils and citizens utility performance. Share with all 18 LGs and seek approval of PSA wording. 2. Initiate activities on addressing key regulatory gaps related to local service delivery in the environmental and economic sectors. 3. Develop methodology and questionnaires for conducting an initial Citizen Satisfaction Survey in all 18 partner local governments. Distribute results for each partner Local government and publish results, which will be used for baseline on citizen satisfaction levels with local authorities.

Main phase officially started in June 2016. 1. Prepared draft Public Service Agreements (PSAs) detailing roles and responsibilities in terms of water supply and wastewater management services in target localities, including concrete oversight by LG councils and citizens utility performance. Drafts shared with all 18 LGs for agreement on PSA wording and initiated preparations for adoption on LG level. 2. Initial assessment conducted and basic legal gaps identified and recommendations provided for both environmental and economic sectors, with input from all project stakeholders from public and private sectors. 3. Developed methodology and questionnaires for conducting an initial Citizen Satisfaction Survey in all 18 partner local governments. Completed surveys for 5,750 individual survey responses. Distributed and published results for each partner Local government. Established baseline on citizen satisfaction levels with local authorities as of 2016 year-end.

activity-description.narrative: Floods affected population of Bosnia and Herzegovina

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

Indicator for Objective 1: Number of dwellings in flood-affected areas repaired (target value: 4,000). Number of vulnerable people within flood-affected areas returned home (target value: 15,400). Number of comprehensive National Risk Assessment surveys conducted
Indicator for Objective 2: Number of flood-affected local governments benefitting from rehabilitated public services and infrastructure Number of educational institutions in affected areas rehabilitated and reequipped: target value Number of children benefiting from rehabilitated and reequipped educational infrastructure in affected areas Number of municipal public administration facilities in affected areas rehabilitated Number of citizens benefiting from restored/improved municipal administrative service delivery in flood-affected areas Number of healthcare facilities in affected areas rehabilitated Number of citizens benefiting from restored/improved healthcare services in affected areas Number of social welfare facilities in flood-affected areas rehabilitated Number of representatives of vulnerable groups in affected areas benefiting from restored/improved social services Number of child-friendly spaces constructed to ensure temporary learning and playing facilities for children in affected areas Number of flood-affected local governments benefitting from rehabilitated public services and infrastructure km of local roads and number of bridges in flood-affected areas rehabilitated Number of flood-affected local governments benefitting from rehabilitated public services and infrastructure Number of critical water and sanitation facilities in flood-affected areas reconstructed Number of households in flood-affected areas benefiting directly from improved water and sanitation services.
Indicator for Objective 3: Number of jobs in agriculture and local businesses retained or created in affected areas Number of MSMEs supported to restore economic activity Number of

comment.narrative:
Baseline for Objective 1: 39,231 damaged homes in BiH.
Baseline for Objective 2: 120 educational facilities, 8 municipal buildings damaged; Recovery Needs Assessment and based on data recorded by the enterprise survey, an additional 33,500 wage workers were directly affected by the floods and are at immediate risk. Additional information received after the conclusion of the enterprise survey by the Ministry of Labour and Veterans of RS stated that approximately 20,000 jobs remain at risk in RS due to the flood.
Baseline for Objective 3: 81 affected local governments benefiting from rehabilitated public services and infrastructure Recovery Needs Assessment (2014).

448 dwellings in flood-affected areas repaired (target value: 4,640). 1,537 vulnerable people within flood-affected areas returned home/resume life in normal living conditions 7 educational institutions in affected areas rehabilitated and reequipped

448 dwellings in flood-affected areas repaired (target value: 4,400). 1,537 vulnerable people within flood-affected areas returned home/resume life in normal living conditions 7 educational institutions in affected areas rehabilitated and reequipped 65,000 children benefiting from rehabilitated and reequipped educational infrastructure in affected areas 3 municipal public administration facilities in affected areas rehabilitated 1 healthcare facilities in affected areas rehabilitated 1 social welfare facility in flood-affected areas rehabilitated 38,559 representatives of vulnerable groups in affected areas benefiting from restored/improved social services 7 local roads and infrastructure reconstructed 1 critical water and sanitation facilities in flood-affected areas reconstructed 506 jobs in agriculture and local businesses retained or created in affected areas

description.narrative:
Indicator for Objective 1: Number of dwellings in flood-affected areas repaired (target value: 4,000). Number of vulnerable people within flood-affected areas returned home (target value: 15,400). Number of comprehensive National Risk Assessment surveys conducted
Indicator for Objective 2: Number of flood-affected local governments benefitting from rehabilitated public services and infrastructure Number of educational institutions in affected areas rehabilitated and reequipped: target value Number of children benefiting from rehabilitated and reequipped educational infrastructure in affected areas Number of municipal public administration facilities in affected areas rehabilitated Number of citizens benefiting from restored/improved municipal administrative service delivery in flood-affected areas Number of healthcare facilities in affected areas rehabilitated Number of citizens benefiting from restored/improved healthcare services in affected areas Number of social welfare facilities in flood-affected areas rehabilitated Number of representatives of vulnerable groups in affected areas benefiting from restored/improved social services Number of child-friendly spaces constructed to ensure temporary learning and playing facilities for children in affected areas Number of flood-affected local governments benefitting from rehabilitated public services and infrastructure km of local roads and number of bridges in flood-affected areas rehabilitated Number of flood-affected local governments benefitting from rehabilitated public services and infrastructure Number of critical water and sanitation facilities in flood-affected areas reconstructed Number of households in flood-affected areas benefiting directly from improved water and sanitation services.
Indicator for Objective 3: Number of jobs in agriculture and local businesses retained or created in affected areas Number of MSMEs supported to restore economic activity Number of

comment.narrative:
Baseline for Objective 1: 39,231 damaged homes in BiH.
Baseline for Objective 2: 120 educational facilities, 8 municipal buildings damaged; Recovery Needs Assessment and based on data recorded by the enterprise survey, an additional 33,500 wage workers were directly affected by the floods and are at immediate risk. Additional information received after the conclusion of the enterprise survey by the Ministry of Labour and Veterans of RS stated that approximately 20,000 jobs remain at risk in RS due to the flood.
Baseline for Objective 3: 81 affected local governments benefiting from rehabilitated public services and infrastructure Recovery Needs Assessment (2014).

448 dwellings in flood-affected areas repaired (target value: 4,640). 1,537 vulnerable people within flood-affected areas returned home/resume life in normal living conditions 7 educational institutions in affected areas rehabilitated and reequipped

title.narrative: Climate resilient flood management in Vrbas River Basin

description.narrative: Technology transfer for climate resilient flood management in Vrbas River Basin

title.narrative: Technology transfer for climate resilient flood management in Vrbas River Basin
Climate resilient flood management in Vrbas River Basin
Climate resilient flood management in Vrbas River Basin
Climate resilient flood management in Vrbas River Basin
Climate resilient flood management in Vrbas River Basin
Climate resilient flood management in Vrbas River Basin

description.narrative: Technology transfer for climate resilient flood management in Vrbas River Basin

activity-description.narrative: Floods risks mapping and management in the Vrbas River Basin, Bosnia and Herzegovina

description.narrative:
Project started in 2015.
1. Number of new technologies transferred to Bosnia and Herzegovina as part of a methodology for strategic flood risk management. 2. Vrbas river basin (12% of BiH territory) covered by an automated hydrometric monitoring network for effective Flood Forecasting and Early Warning. 3. Policy environment and regulatory framework for adaptation related technology transfer established or strengthened 4. Strengthened Capacity to transfer appropriate adaptation technologies 5. Number of institutions enabled to modify risk management strategies based on introduced vulnerability, loss and damages assessment and improved hydrometric monitoring technologies 6. Number of people in target basin benefiting from flood risk management adaptation technologies, tools, and adaptation strategies, and are less exposed to flood risk 7. Availability of innovative non-structural measures introduced and implemented as part of climate adaptation strategies to provide improved resilience to communities (include agric. 8. Number of communities benefitting from introduced forecasting, early warning, response and recovery technologies to support local communities at risk of flooding

comment.narrative:
Project started in 2015.
1. 0 strategic flood risk management technologies in Bosnia and Herzegovina 2. No automatized and centralized hydrometric network in Vrbas river basin 3. No policy/regulatory framework for adaptation related technology transfer in place 4. Local professionals are unaware of adaptation technologies 5. Most of the socio-economic information required to assess flood damages, losses, exposure and vulnerability is not currently available and is not collected systematically and gender-disaggregation of data not systematically done. 6.Current approach limited of inclusion of local communities, and particularly the vulnerable groups 7.Current approach to flood risk management is structural flood protection measures and non-structural measures are not considered to be adaptive measure. 8. 0 communities benefitting from introduced forecasting, early warning, response and recovery technologies to support local communities at risk of flooding.

1. Complete topographic (LiDAR) survey for flood risk area in Vrbas River Basin. 2. Develop methodology for flood hazard ans risk mapping in Bosnia and Herzegovina. 3. Complete hydrological modelling of Vrbas River Basin. 4. Initiate development of the National Adaptation Plan for Bosnia and Herzegovina. 5. Create institutional set-up for flood forecasting and early warning system in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

1. LiDAR survey completed. 2. Methodology for flood hazard and flood risk mapping finalized and adopted by local authorities. 3. Hydrological model for Vrbas River Basin, which integrates climate change models, completed. 4. UNFCCC focal point request for UNDP assistance in developing National Adaptation Plan received. 5. Analysis of institutional responsibilities in flood forecasting and early warning system in Bosnia and Herzegovina completed and proposal for set-up in Bosnia and Herzegovina submitted to relevant institutions.

title.narrative: Project Document "Disaster Risk Reduction Initiative in Bosnia and Herzegovina"
Project document: Support to Flood Recovery and Risk Mitigation

description.narrative: Project will strengthen policy and institutional frameworks for DRR. Project will enhance existing capacities to build a reliable and efficient preparedness and response system and will build resilience of local communities.

activity-description.narrative: Bosnia and Herzegovina

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1.Number of organized disaster risk reduction platforms organized in BiH resulting in enhanced capacities of responsible institutions from all levels of government. 2. Number of educational events aimed at increased understanding of Disaster Risk Reduction and responsibilities of different actors in this area 3. Level of Capacities and conditions under which Civil Service Protection agencies in BiH operate. 4. Number of roaming dog management plans adopted in selected municipalities in BiH.

comment.narrative: 1. Disaster Risk Reduction policy of BiH is decentralized to all levels of government with different government levels without clear roles and responsibilities and with limited coordination. 2. Lack of understanding of Disaster Risk Reduction and responsibilities of different actors in this area. 3. Insufficient level of equipment at disposal by Civil Service Protection agencies in BiH 4. No roaming dog management plans adopted in Lopare and Sanski Most.

1. Rehabilitation of 5 landslide areas 2. Support to BiH DRR Platform 3. Development of innovative disaster risk reduction tool compiling hazard-related, geographic, land usage, infrastructure, territorial and socio-economic data offering information-based disaster risk-related scenarios and solutions for local decision-makers.

1. Successful rehabilitation of 4 landslide areas protecting 35 houses and roads 2. BiH DRR Platform supported through organization of annual conference, web-site development and 3. Disaster Risk Analysis System devleoped
